docs.lead_paragraph: Arkansas ARKANSAS SHAKESPEARE THEATER Conway, June 7-July 1. Whether you prefer your summer Shakespeare outside or indoors, this festival can accommodate you. ''Twelfth Night'' will be presented on the green at the Village at Hendrix in Conway and at Wildwood Park for the Arts in Little Rock. At the indoor Reynolds Performance Hall in Conway, you can catch ''Richard III'' or ''The Tempest.'' Shakespeare plays are big business come summer, but this Arkansas company, like many theaters focused on Shakespeare, branches out: The indoor stage will also feature the Huck Finn musical ''Big River''; (866) 810-0012, arkshakes.com.
docs.snippet: “As You Like It,” “Much Ado About Nothing” and “Richard III” are among the popular choices for this summer’s theater festivals.

docs.lead_paragraph: The decline is attributable to increases in contraception and in AIDS drugs, and to greater numbers of births attended by those with medical training.

headline.seo: Maternal Deaths Plunged Over 2 Decades, U.N. Reports
headline.main: Maternal Deaths Plunged Over 2 Decades, to About 287,000 in 2010, U.N. Reports
headline.print_headline: Maternal Deaths Plunged Over 2 Decades, to About 287,000 in 2010, U.N. Reports

docs.abstract: Consortium of United Nations agencies releases report showing that the number of women dying from pregnancy and childbirth dropped to 287,000 in 2010, down 47 percent from 543,000 in 1990.
docs.snippet: The decline is attributable to increases in contraception and in AIDS drugs, and to greater numbers of births attended by those with medical training.

docs.lead_paragraph: At the orphanage his father founded as part of his missionary work in the Philippines, the children still toss around a football Tim Tebow left for them.

headline.seo: For Tim Tebow, an Example Set Long Ago

docs.abstract: Bob Tebow, father of NFL quarterback Tim Tebow, founded an orphanage in the Philippines in 1992 as part of his missionary work, and children there play with a football left for them by Tim on one of his many visits.
docs.snippet: At the orphanage his father founded as part of his missionary work in the Philippines, the children still toss around a football Tim Tebow left for them.

docs.lead_paragraph: An examination of 42 studies showed that intrauterine devices had a higher success rate in preventing pregnancy after unprotected sex than two pills that are used more often.

headline.seo: IUD May Be Best Emergency Contraception, Analysis Shows
headline.main: Regimens: IUD May Be Best Emergency Contraception
headline.print_headline: Regimens: IUD May Be Best Emergency Contraception

docs.abstract: Review of several studies published in journal Human Reproduction finds that that the insertion of an intrauterine device after unprotected sex is the most effective and safest method of emergency contraception.
docs.snippet: An examination of 42 studies showed that intrauterine devices had a higher success rate in preventing pregnancy after unprotected sex than two pills that are used more often.

docs.lead_paragraph: Performing Caesarean deliveries extensively in 49 poor countries would save 16,800 mothers’ lives annually and prevent many vaginal tears, a new study found.

headline.seo: Study Seeks More Access to Caesarean Births in Poor Countries
headline.main: Caesareans Are Cost-Effective in Poor Countries, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Women's Health: Caesareans Are Cost-Effective In Poor Countries, Study Finds

docs.abstract: Study in journal PLoS One finds that performing Caesarean deliveries extensively in 49 poor countries would save 16,800 mothers’ lives annually and prevent many fistulas; also finds that relatively cheap cost of the operation would be offset by long-term gains.
docs.snippet: Performing Caesarean deliveries extensively in 49 poor countries would save 16,800 mothers’ lives annually and prevent many vaginal tears, a new study found.

docs.lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE WEIGHT OF THE NATION More than two-thirds of the adults in the United States and one-third of children are overweight, leading to an increase in deaths from heart disease, Type 2 diabetes, cancer, stroke and kidney disease. This four-part documentary -- a collaboration by HBO, the Institute of Medicine, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the National Institutes of Health -- is at the center of a public health campaign that includes a book, a social media component and an effort to reach more than 40,000 community groups. Part 3, ''Children in Crisis,'' looks at the struggle of overweight children and at their medical issues; above, a middle school gym class in Austin, Tex. It also examines school lunch standards and the debate over the definition of good nutrition among food and beverage makers, researchers and the government. The conclusion, ''Challenges,'' at 9:10, explores factors behind the obesity epidemic, including subsidized agriculture, evolutionary biology, racial and socioeconomic disparities, physical inactivity and the strong influence of the food and beverage industry. ''It wouldn't surprise me if people look back on the early part of the 21st century and call this the obesity era,'' says Dr. Thomas Farley, the New York City health commissioner. 9 A.M. (Sundance) ENCOUNTERS AT THE END OF THE WORLD (2008) For this documentary Werner Herzog traveled to Antarctica, where he met scientists and journeymen at the American outpost McMurdo Station and the penguins, seals, clams and jellyfish that surround them on what might as well be another planet. ''Few filmmakers make the end of days seem as hauntingly beautiful as Werner Herzog does, or as inexorable,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. One of the film's beauties, Ms. Dargis said, ''is that all the furry and floating animals are no more wondrous than the bipeds tramping through and around McMurdo: the linguist turned philosopher, the banker turned bus driver, and the female adventurer who, for drama and odd entertainment, likes to have herself zipped up in a carryall bag. (She's her own baggage.) Mr. Herzog opens his mind, heart and eyes to all these wayfarers who -- despite the persistent strain of melancholy that touches each and every person who appears on camera -- seem eerily at peace at the bottom of the world.'' The film received an Oscar nomination for best documentary feature.
